channel.title: BBC Sport
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see https://www.bbc.co.uk/usingthebbc/terms-of-use/#15metadataandrssfeeds for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Bellingham on bench v Serbia as O'Reilly wins first cap
item.description: Jude Bellingham starts on the bench for England's World Cup qualifier against Serbia, with Morgan Rogers in the number 10 role.

item.title: What are the 'mind-altering' shoes England players are wearing?
item.description: England are always looking at ways they can gain an advantage for their players as prepare to try to win the World Cup and now they have turned to fluorescent red 'mind-altering' shoes as tool to help them do that.

item.title: The Ratcliffe revolution - inside Man Utd's exodus and rebuild
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of how Sir Jim Ratcliffe ripped apart and rebuilt Manchester United's leadership team.

item.title: What's up with Wales and Spurs 'mystery' Johnson?
item.description: Brennan Johnson should be a key player for Wales but, as well as being in and out of Spurs' team, he finds himself out of favour for his country.

item.title: 'Scotland players can instantly write themselves into history books'
item.description: Head coach Steve Clarke says "the chance is there" for his Scotland squad to "instantly write their names in the history books" should they qualify for a first World Cup in 27 years - and the first of nine of their lifetimes.

item.title: 'Kane, Bellingham and Foden can't play together' - is Tuchel right?
item.description: After England manager Thomas Tuchel said Harry Kane, Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden cannot play in the same team, BBC Sport looks at his attacking options.

item.title: 'Historically for men' - WSL wants stadium changes
item.description: The company which runs English professional women's football calls for more female-friendly stadiums.

item.title: Is anything being done about poor player behaviour?
item.description: Player behaviour didn't feature in Reinventing Football, our manifesto for the game, but it was a big focus for fans.

item.title: 'VAR has to rein its neck in' - how I'd change football for the fans
item.description: In his BBC Sport column, former Premier League manager Tony Pulis looks at which laws he would change in football.

item.title: Could a stopped clock end time-wasting in football?
item.description: Would a game of two halves of 30 minutes, with the watch stopped when the ball is out, really improve football?

item.title: How new rules would change way football is played
item.description: BBC Sport has been looking at possible ways of changing football - but what impact could different laws have on tactics?

item.title: Meet the man who played in two games, in two countries... in one day
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of Soren Lerby, who once played for Denmark and Bayern Munich on the same day - in different countries.

item.title: Real's Endrick closes in on Lyon loan
item.description: Real Madrid are in advanced talks with Lyon over sending 19-year-old forward Endrick on loan to the Ligue 1 side in January.

item.title: Turkish FA bans 102 players in betting probe
item.description: Turkey's Football Federation gives bans to 102 players from its top two divisions for "betting-related activities".

item.title: Man Utd face legal action over sex abuse claims
item.description: The allegations relate to Billy Watts, who worked at the club's Cliff training ground in the 1980s.

item.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
item.description: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

item.title: The ex-Peterborough man helping World Cup dreams come true
item.description: BBC Sport looks at the England-raised former DR Congo defender who speaks eight languages and his role in recruiting European players for the national team.

item.title: Why Bodo/Glimt miracle worker might appeal to Celtic
item.description: Reported Celtic target Kjetil Knutsen has taken Bodo/Glimt and Norwegian football to new heights.

item.title: Rolfo & Malard score as Man Utd beat PSG
item.description: Manchester United continue their winning run in the Women's Champions League, beating Paris St-Germain on Mary Earps' return to Old Trafford.

item.title: Park reflects on 'incredible' win over PSG at Old Trafford
item.description: Manchester United's Jess Park reflects on an "incredible" night at Old Trafford as her side beat Paris St-Germain 2-1 in the Women's Champions League.

item.title: 'There was anger' - Clarke admits to Belarus frustration
item.description: Scotland manager Steve Clarke says he wanted to provoke a reaction from his players as they laboured to a 2-1 win over Belarus last month.

item.title: Carmona scores 'extraordinary' equaliser for PSG
item.description: Paris St-Germain's Olga Carmona fires home an "extraordinary" equaliser for her side in their Women's Champions League match against Manchester United at Old Trafford.

item.title: 'A stroke of genius!' - Malard fires Man Utd ahead against PSG
item.description: Manchester United forward Melvine Malard beats Mary Earps with a superb curling effort to give her side the lead against PSG in their Women's Champions League match at Old Trafford.

item.title: Sheff Utd sign experienced striker Bamford
item.description: Sheffield United sign former Leeds United striker Patrick Bamford on a short-term deal until January.

item.title: What has led to Liverpool's seven-game winless WSL run?
item.description: With just one point from their first seven Women's Super League matches this season Liverpool are not where they want to be, but the January transfer window could be key to their campaign.

item.title: Kane a top target for Barcelona - Thursday's gossip
item.description: England and Bayern Munich striker Harry Kane is a leading target for Barcelona, Crystal Palace midfielder Adam Wharton tops Chelsea transfer list, Juventus halt contract talks with Kenan Yildiz, plus more.

item.title: Wyke targets 'one more game' after horror injury
item.description: Carlisle United forward Charlie Wyke talks about the "horrendous" time he has had since breaking his leg in October 2024.

item.title: Oscar thanks fans for 'messages and prayers'
item.description: Former Chelsea and Brazil midfielder Oscar thanks fans for their "messages and prayers" after being hospitalised with a heart issue.

item.title: Earps return 'talk of Manchester' but Middleton-Patel steals show
item.description: Manchester United's victory over PSG was significant - but conversation before, during and after was dominated by goalkeepers.

item.title: Which stadiums are hosting Euro 2028?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team provide a guide to the venues for Euro 2028 in England, Scotland, Wales and the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: England's place is booked - what's still at stake in final World Cup qualifiers?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at who has qualified for next year's Fifa World Cup.

item.title: NI the 'strongest we've been' - Peacock-Farrell
item.description: Northern Ireland goalkeeper Bailey Peacock-Farrell feels Michael O'Neill's squad is "the strongest we've been" as they prepare for Friday's crunch World Cup qualifier away to Slovakia.

item.title: Former defender Edwards' return to Wolves - a gamble all round?
item.description: Wolves finally have their man. But how big a gamble have the Premier League side made in appointing Rob Edwards?

item.title: Exeter City stadium fire deemed accidental
item.description: Dozens of firefighters attended the incident amid fears it would spread to the stadium's stands.

item.title: 'I don't feel pressure of being Ronaldinho's son'
item.description: Hull City academy winger Joao Mendes says he does not feel extra pressure to succeed because he is the son of Brazil legend Ronaldinho.

item.title: Cardiff to host opening match of Euro 2028
item.description: Cardiff will host the opening game of Euro 2028, with the semi-finals and final set to take place at London's Wembley Stadium.

item.title: Mainz lose court appeal over El Ghazi wrongful dismissal
item.description: German club Mainz have lost a court appeal for wrongful dismissal by Dutch winger Anwar El Ghazi over social media posts regarding the Israel-Gaza conflict.

item.title: How Arteta-McVay bond helped Arsenal & Rams become title contenders
item.description: The head coaches of the Los Angeles Rams and Arsenal, teams from different sports in the same ownership group, have developed a bond that has helped both become title contenders.

item.title: Robertson row shows the problems VAR can never fix
item.description: Football's subjective laws mean supporters will never get on board with all decisions, and that's a problem for VAR.

item.title: New dad Brooks determined to realise World Cup dream
item.description: Cancer-free and a new dad, Bournemouth midfielder David Brooks is more determined than ever to play for Wales at a World Cup.

item.title: 'Salary cap would be legally challenged by clubs'
item.description: A Premier League proposal to introduce a controversial salary cap "cannot be imposed unilaterally", says Professional Footballers' Association chief executive Maheta Molango.

item.title: Break-in at Sterling's house while family at home
item.description: Burglars break into England forward Raheem Sterling's house while he and his family are at home.

item.title: How does Clarke rouse Scotland for tenure-defining games?
item.description: The next four days could define Steve Clarke's Scotland reign, so how can he inspire his team for a seismic World Cup qualifying double-header?

item.title: How can Northern Ireland qualify for the 2026 World Cup?
item.description: With two World Cup qualifying fixtures remaining, where do Northern Ireland stand in the play-off picture for the tournament next summer?

item.title: How can Scotland qualify for 2026 World Cup?
item.description: Scotland will finish either first or second in their World Cup qualification group. But how do they reach the finals?

item.title: 1,000 games in, Guardiola has new energy for new era
item.description: Sunday began with a celebration of Pep Guardiola and ended in the same manner, with the Manchester City boss showing he has new energy in a new era for the club.

item.title: Hoardings, showers & pink dressing rooms - the 'creative' ways clubs get an edge
item.description: After Sunderland moved advertising hoardings to stifle Arsenal's long throws, BBC Sport looks at some other creative ways teams have tried to gain an advantage.

item.title: Does a change in manager lead to more injuries?
item.description: Physiotherapist Ben Warburton says it's "very well known" that a new coach of a team will prompt "an increase of injury incidence".

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: Why are England called the Three Lions?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain where the three lions on the England shirt came from.

item.title: When is the 2026 World Cup draw?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore when the World Cup draw is, how the seeding works and who has qualified so far.

item.title: Who is Wilfried Nancy?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team take a look who MLS manager Wilfried Nancy is.

item.title: Why VAR gets involved in some penalties but not others
item.description: It was a weekend of VAR penalty decisions in the Premier League, with spot-kicks awarded, cancelled and ignored. BBC Sport explains why.

item.title: Why can Channel Islands players play for England?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at why players born in the Channel Islands like Alex Scott can represent England at a senior level.

item.title: What are the Fifa Best Awards?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain what the Fifa Best Awards are, who can vote and who the nominees are.

item.title: Why do footballers tape up their wrists?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why footballers use tape to wrap their wrists.

item.title: How to follow Scotland's crucial qualifiers on BBC
item.description: Scotland's matches away to Greece and at home to Denmark could determine if the nation reaches a World Cup for the first time since 1998, and you watch them exclusively on the BBC.

item.title: Collum backs decision not to send off Trusty - gossip
item.description: SFA referee chief indicates support for big Hampden call as Hearts' title hopes are doubted.

item.title: Aberdeen to trial alcohol sales at Scottish Premiership match
item.description: Supporters will be able to buy alcoholic drinks at the game against Kilmarnock next month.

item.title: Maccabi fan ban was due to hooliganism, say police
item.description: West Midlands Police did not previously reveal its reasons because "it wasn't deemed helpful".

item.title: Referees among suspects sought in match-fixing probe
item.description: Turkish prosecutors issue detention orders for 21 people - including 17 referees and two club presidents - as part of a major investigation into betting and match fixing.

item.title: Watch live Bundesliga games on Friday nights on the BBC
item.description: BBC Sport announce broadcasting rights for Bundesliga matches for the 2025-26 and 2026-27 seasons.

item.title: Inside Bellingham's tough start at Dortmund
item.description: Jobe Bellingham impressed after first arriving at Borussia Dortmund in the summer, but has since struggled to find his best form.

item.title: Wales aim to halt losing streak in Spain
item.description: Rhian Wilkinson's side will travel to Spain to play Switzerland in one of two international friendlies next month.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
